awd_titl_txt: Hydrothermal Brines: New Media for the Synthesis and Crystal Growth of Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Summary
This project explores new solid-state materials with potentially useful properties. The funding from the Solid State and Materials Chemistry Program supports continued development of a novel approach to synthesis of new materials, specifically a high temperature hydrothermal technique in which reactions are performed in water at exceptionally high temperatures (700 degrees C) and pressures (20,000 psi). These conditions are similar to those deep within the Earth, and often result in formation of high quality single crystals of new products. Such extreme reaction conditions are almost unknown in any other laboratories in the world. Because of this, compounds can be prepared that are completely new and unanticipated, and challenge existing theories of structure and bonding. Many of these unusual new materials have unexpectedly useful properties. Some can be used in lasers, ultrahigh resolution micromachining, new magnetic devices and possibly quantum communication and quantum computers. This research is directly applicable to one of the NSF Big Ideas: "The Quantum Leap: Leading the Next Quantum Revolution". The new techniques used in this program typically lead to crystals of exceptional size and quality, therefore they can be studied in greater detail than many other materials. The comprehensive investigation of these new crystal materials provides important insights into the next generation of new materials. Because the techniques employed in this research are used almost nowhere else in the world, the students in this program learn a unique skill set enabling them to stand out as the next generation of researchers.

Technical Summary
This program, funded by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program in the Division of Materials Research,  is a next-stage extension of high temperature hydrothermal synthesis as a route to new solid-state compounds. The primary emphasis in this project is on the investigation of a new class of mineralizers, namely hydrothermal brines. Brines are fluids containing concentrated salts like halides and carbonates. Such fluids have received almost no systematic laboratory study, but preliminary investigation suggests that they are excellent media for the synthesis and single crystal growth of an enormous new class of interesting compounds. The program focuses on open shell first row transition metal ions that are complexed by a range of oxyanion building blocks. These include vanadates, phosphates, germanates, gallates, stannates and other related building blocks containing a variety of structural and bridging characteristics. The new crystals exhibit a number of attractive physical properties including acentricity, polarity and frustrated magnetic behavior. The research targets specific types of compounds with these desirable properties for new piezoelectrics, multiferroics and similar materials. Because the synthesis techniques employed in this research are used almost nowhere else in the world, the students in this program learn a unique skill set enabling them to stand out as the next generation of researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the growth of new materials containing combinations of open shell transition metal ions and tetrahedral building blocks, such as vanadate (VO43-), molybdate (MoO42) and germanate (GeO44-). The compounds can be made as high quality single crystals, enabling detailed measurements of their physical properties. The crystals are synthesized using a high temperature hydrothermal method in water heated to 500-700˚C at 1-2000 psi, which was developed as part of previous NSF projects. In this program special emphasis was placed on the development of brines as the reaction media. This project found that aqueous phases with high alkali halide and carbonate concentrations are particularly amenable to the synthesis and crystal growth of the target compounds.  Even small variations in brine compositions lead to significant differences in product formation. The nonmagnetic building blocks act as bridging units and spacers that link the magnetic transition metal ions and provide enormous structural versatility. Over the course of the project the most attractive materials were classified as 1-D chains or 2-D layers, with a growing emphasis on frustrated magnetic behavior. The first row transition metal ions such as Mn2+, Fe2+, Fe3+, Co2+, Ni2+ and Cu2+ provided the richest chemistry and magnetic behavior when combined with vanadates and molybdates. This wide combinatorial palate coupled with the variations in brine chemistry provide an almost infinite variation of interesting new materials.

Intellectual Merit: Over the course of the project gradually increasing attention was paid to the magnetic properties of the new materials being isolated. In particular a collaboration with Oak Ridge National Labs was developed that employed neutron scattering to obtain the magnetic structures of many new materials. We found that atomic structures alone are not sufficient to predict the magnetic structures of these frustrated materials, but that elastic neutron scattering was needed to provide understanding of the magnetic vector lattices. These neutron scattering studies are also enhanced by our ability to grow large high quality single crystals of the materials. With these we can get both single crystal neutron structures, and magnetic structural data in oriented magnetic fields. In 1-D materials the magnetic structures allow us to enable us to look at the difference between intrachain and interchain coupling. In many cases the stronger intrachain coupling can be perturbed by the weaker interchain coupling to create cycloidal structures of the magnetic vectors. These can lead to more complex properties such as induced electric dipoles, which in turn can form multiferroic materials. Similarly, we prepared a series of 2-D layered materials and began studying their magnetic structures with an emphasis on their interlayer interactions. Again, the weak interlayer couplings induced a range of extremely complex magnetic structures that may be able to display multiferroic behavior. Over the course of this project, we found that the careful study of the brine media led to a wide range of new materials. We gradually gained a deeper understanding of the magnetic structures of these materials, and this understanding could eventually lead to the potential rational design of multifunctional materials. 

Broader Impacts: A primary purpose of this project is the education of junior researchers, particularly graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. A number of junior researchers were supported by the project and went on the advanced careers in science. For example, the primary postdoctoral fellow on this project, Tiffany Pellizerri, is now on the faculty of Eastern Illinois University. One important component of the project is the designed growth of large single crystals of target compounds. Designed single crystal growth is a critical area of science that has mostly gone fallow in the US. Another important aspect of this project is the interaction with Oak Ridge National Lab. Not only does this collaboration provide critical scientific data, it also provides the junior researchers important exposure to large national laboratories and their capabilities.
